Connolly, a Representative in Congress from the Commonwealth of Virginia: Prepared statement.......... 77 Written response from the Honorable Jane Harman to question submitted for the record by the Honorable Dina Titus, a Representative in Congress from the State of Nevada............ 79 </option> <Doc-title>CONFRONTING THE IRANIAN CHALLENGE</Doc-title> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker=""> The committee met, pursuant to notice, at 10:00 a.m., in room 2172 Rayburn House Office Building, Hon. Edward Royce (chairman of the committee) presiding. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Chairman Royce">All right. We will call this hearing to order.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Chairman Royce">Later today, the President will announce whether he intends to keep the United States in the Iran nuclear agreement. This is earlier than expected.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Chairman Royce">Over the past 6 months, the Trump administration has urged France and Germany and Britain to help address the full range of threats posed by the Iranian regime.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Chairman Royce">U.S. negotiators have rightly pushed for fixes to the deeply-flawed agreement, including stronger inspections, new sanctions on Iran's ballistic missiles program, and a solution to the deal's sunset problem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Chairman Royce">Addressing these serious shortcomings is a must to keep Iran from threatening the United States and our allies with a nuclear weapon.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Chairman Royce">As I've said, this agreement's fundamental flaw is that it trades temporary restrictions for permanent sanctions relief.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Chairman Royce">Today, this committee will examine the decision before the President. As the members of this committee know, I opposed the nuclear deal and so did a bipartisan majority of the committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Chairman Royce">And why was this so? Because the Obama administration, in the negotiations, ditched its key goals. The deal does not shut off Iran's path to a nuclear weapon. It does not allow inspectors ``anywhere, anytime, 24/7 access.'' It does not stop the regime's pursuit of intercontinental ballistic missiles and it gives Tehran an infusion of cash to support more of its terrorist activities around the world.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Chairman Royce">That said, I believe the best path forward at this point is to continue to fix these flaws as we enforce the hell out of the deal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Chairman Royce">The Obama administration has put us in a tough spot. Roughly, $100 billion was given to Iran. At least $1.7 billion of that was an apparent cash ransom payment, stacked on pallets and flown, against the advice of the Justice Department and other officials, to the Iranian regime at the time when the three hostages were released.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Chairman Royce">Much of these funds have likely found their way into the hands of the Revolutionary Guard Corps. Tearing up the nuclear deal will not recover this cash. That toothpaste isn't going back into the tube.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Chairman Royce">It also won't help galvanize our allies into addressing Iran's dangerous activities that threaten us all. I fear a withdrawal would actually set back these efforts and Congress has heard nothing about an alternative.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Chairman Royce">Last week's move by Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to unveil Iran's secret nuclear weapons archive reminds us all what is at stake. Despite its repeated denials, Iran had a comprehensive program to design, to test, and to build a nuclear weapon.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Chairman Royce">Of course, this begs the question--what is Iran hiding today? Shouldn't we have better inspections? Remember, the deal's existing restrictions expire in the short years ahead.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Chairman Royce">The key restriction--the ability to quickly enrich uranium--begins to phase out in less than 8 years. We should be able to get an agreement with the Europeans to fix these serious flaws.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Chairman Royce">I understand we have made encouraging progress in recent weeks. If we don't have an agreement today, let's double down on diplomacy and get a deal in the weeks ahead. The Europeans need to get to yes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Chairman Royce"> And now I'll turn to our ranking member, Mr. Engel of New York, for his opening statement. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Engel</speaker> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Engel">Thank you, Mr. Chairman. I concur with your opening statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Mr. Engel">To our witnesses, welcome to the Foreign Affairs Committee. We are grateful for the decades of public service that all of you collectively represent, and Jane, it's always good to see you back on Capitol Hill.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Mr. Engel">Once again, we find ourselves against a phony deadline dealing with the Iran nuclear agreement. Once again, the President has created a crisis where none exists and kept us all wondering what he's going to do.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Mr. Engel">This administration has promised a comprehensive approach for dealing with the regime in Tehran. Yet, 16 months along, the Trump administration's Iran policy seems to be do nothing until the clock runs out and make unrealistic demands of Congress or of our international partners, and up to this point, kick the can down the road a few more months.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Engel">The President has until Saturday to decide whether to continue waiving nuclear-related sanctions on Iran, though reporting this morning suggests that he will announce an end to those waivers today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="Mr. Engel">I hope he understands the stakes. If he puts those sanctions back into effect, the United States will be in violation of our obligations under the nuclear deal and trigger the deal's collapse.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="Mr. Engel">The argument that the deal would continue without American participation is simply not true. There is no having it both ways, and let's be clear, President Trump would be the one who pulled the plug and undermined American credibility.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="Mr. Engel">I've said more times than I can count that I opposed the deal when it was announced. I voted against it on the House floor and I continue to have doubts about the JCPOA, and I have doubts about whether it will prevent Iran from developing a nuclear weapon over the long term.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="Mr. Engel">But I know for certain that pulling out of the deal now will make a nuclear-armed Iran a much more immediate threat. Some of my chief concerns with the agreement were the sunset provisions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="28" speaker="Mr. Engel">But those sunsets come many years in the future. What's the emergency now? Why the hysterical rush if the United States undermines the deal for sunsets that expire in 10 or 15 years would instead expire at the end of the week?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="29" speaker="Mr. Engel">Iran would race headlong toward a bomb while keeping the cash that's been freed up over the last few years of sanctions relief.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="30" speaker="Mr. Engel">If we want to extend the sunsets, and many of us do--and that was one of my major objections to the deal--let's work cooperatively with our allies rather than ruining any chance we have of keeping the Iranians from the bomb for a longer time.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="31" speaker="Mr. Engel">Reimposing sanctions would also have far-reaching consequences besides terminating the JCPOA. We could find ourselves slapping serious punitive measures on our closest friends and allies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="32" speaker="Mr. Engel">Furthermore, it would send a terrible signal that the United States does not live up to its word and with North Korea negotiations ramping up, that is the exact wrong time to send that message.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="33" speaker="Mr. Engel">Why would anyone negotiate with us if the minute we got a new administration or a new President they ripped up any agreement in order to get rid of it and start anew?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="34" speaker="Mr. Engel">I think it undermines our credibility and it's the wrong message to send, and I have to note that President Trump could not have been more wrong when he said that killing the Iran deal sends the right message to North Korea.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="35" speaker="Mr. Engel">Frankly, it sends precisely the wrong message, and that message is that the U.S. won't live up to its commitments. At the same time that the United States scuttles the deal, we would lose whatever leverage we have in trying to make the agreement stronger and addressing all of Iran's other aggressive activities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="36" speaker="Mr. Engel">I think there is potential for progress but it requires the United States to lead, work to bring parties back to the table, lean into new negotiations, allow the present deal to continue, and try to build on top of it.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="37" speaker="Mr. Engel">Instead, the administration wants to sit back and say Europe needs to do the hard work or Congress needs to fix it. That's just not the way these things work.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="38" speaker="Mr. Engel">Congress has done its part. We have given the administration all the tools it needs to crack down on Iran for its illegal ballistic missile program, its support for terrorism, its atrocious human rights record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="39" speaker="Mr. Engel">The White House should use these tools to craft what it promised: A comprehensive Iran strategy rather than bringing us to the brink of crisis every 3 months.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="40" speaker="Mr. Engel"> I look forward to hearing our witnesses views on this challenge. I, again, thank the chairman and concur with his remarks, and I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker> <paragraph paraId="41" speaker="Chairman Royce">Thank you, Mr. Engel.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="42" speaker="Chairman Royce">So this morning, I am pleased to welcome our panel. We have got distinguished guests before this committee including Ambassador Lincoln Bloomfield.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="43" speaker="Chairman Royce">He's the chairman emeritus and distinguished fellow at the Stimson Center, and he previously served as the Assistant Secretary of State for Political and Military Affairs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="44" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have Mr. Stephen Rademaker who serves as senior of counsel at Covington and Burling. Previously, he served as the Assistant Secretary of State for Arms Control, before that, the Assistant Secretary of State for International Security and Nonproliferation, and before that, with this committee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="45" speaker="Chairman Royce">We have Jane Harman. She leads the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars. Previously, she served here in the U.S. House of Representatives representing the people of California's 36th District.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="46" speaker="Chairman Royce">And we appreciate all of them being here with us today, and without objection the witnesses' full prepared statements will be made part of the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="47" speaker="Chairman Royce">Members here are going to have 5 calendar days to submit any statements or questions or any extraneous material for the record.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="48" speaker="Chairman Royce">Obviously, the President's announcement yesterday that he'll be making an announcement on the Iran deal this afternoon and the strong expectation that he'll be exiting the agreement changes today's discussion some and it affects, certainly, for the witnesses, their written testimonies, which I've read.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="49" speaker="Chairman Royce">I appreciate the scrambling and I am hopeful that this would be all the more reason why we should be concise here today in terms of your testimony and that way we can hear your expertise in response to our questions.</paragraph>
Hearing.Statement: <opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD, JR., CHAIRMAN</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">And, again, I thank you for being here to discuss these very important topics. We will start with Ambassador Bloomfield and we will ask him to please summarize your remarks if you can. EMERITUS AND DISTINGUISHED FELLOW, THE STIMSON CENTER (FORMER ASSISTANT SECRETARY FOR POLITICAL MILITARY AFFAIRS, U.S.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">DEPARTMENT OF STATE)</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Ambassador Bloomfield. Thank you, Chairman Royce, Ranking Member Engel, members of the committee. Thank you for the honor of being with you this morning.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Like you, I await the President's announcement this afternoon whether he will continue to waive nuclear sanctions on Iran or withdraw the United States from the P5+1 nuclear agreement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">There are valid reasons to maintain the restraints on Iran's nuclear program under the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action. There are also strong criticisms of the accord because it has left the world uncertain as to whether Iran still seeks to develop nuclear weapons in the future.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">I find merit in both points of view and believe that the legitimate concerns of supporters and critics of the JCPOA can both be accommodated if the Congress is prepared to act.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">The Iranian regime's malign activities domestically and regionally require a more effective response and the President is far from alone in his criticism of the nuclear accord.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">The question is what would be a successful policy. It is not enough to be right. The U.S. needs influence, credibility, and leverage over Iran and the problems it is creating.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">If the U.S. pulls out of the JCPOA, I see four serious consequences that we should hope to avoid.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">First, Britain, France, and Germany, our strategic allies who've spent years negotiating this agreement, will be disappointed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Their publics may feel as though we snubbed the best diplomatic efforts of President Macron, Chancellor Merkel, and Minister Boris Johnson.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">If we end up in disputes, attempting to enforce Iran's sanctions against European companies, the West will be divided over the Iran threat.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Secondly, Iran may resume an accelerated rush to build nuclear weapons with no restraints. The head of the Atomic Energy Organization of Iran, Ali Akbar Salehi, recently said that they could resume 20 percent enrichment activities at the Fordow facility in 4 days.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Third, a nuclear arms race could break out in the Middle East. Iran's Arab neighbors across the Persian Gulf declared in 2008 that they will match any weapons capability that Iran possesses--a position reiterated in recent months.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">America's pledge to maintain Israel's qualitative military edge in the region could become meaningless if Iran and its Arab neighbors are racing to build or acquire nuclear weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">The fourth major concern about withdrawing from the JCPOA, even when the CIA director testified last month that Iran is in compliance, is the long-term impact on Presidential diplomacy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">The day that other governments conclude that an executive agreement reached with one administration might easily be cast aside by the next President, they may insist on a treaty, requiring ratification by two-thirds of the Senate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Not only will the House of Representatives be disempowered, but Presidential power to shape foreign policy including trade will be diminished.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">That is why in my prepared statement I have suggested that the Congress amend the Iran Nuclear Agreement Review Act of 2015 so that the President no longer has to certify Iran's compliance every 90 days.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">We and our allies should intensify the identification and inspection of suspicious sites. The reality is that the final milestone in the JCPOA where the International Atomic Energy Agency reaches a ``broader conclusion'' that Iran's nuclear activity is entirely peaceful, will never happen unless all legitimate suspicions can be put to rest.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">If Iran will not extend the duration of sunset clauses in the accord, we should codify the longstanding bipartisan policy that Iran must not have nuclear weapons.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">The President would leave no room for doubt by declaring this as a doctrine.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">A third area of concern is Iran's ballistic missile activity. When a 2010 U.N. prohibition was lifted as part of the accord, Iran immediately began testing missiles.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="24" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Scores of missiles have been fired into Saudi Arabia from Yemen. There must be no financial dealings with any individuals, companies, banks, and organizations supporting Iran's ballistic missile program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="25" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">Five years have passed since President Obama extended the offer to Iran to pursue a path to a more respectful relationship. The nuclear deal was reached.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="26" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">But Iran has shown no interest in changing its ways. For decades the clerical dictatorship has been conducting nonstop geopolitical arson, threatening regional peace and stability, international norms, and U.S. national security interests.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="27" speaker="THE HONORABLE LINCOLN P. BLOOMFIELD">We, and our allies, must stand together and say, ``no more.''</paragraph>

<opening>[The prepared statement of Ambassador Bloomfield follows:]</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Ambassador Bloomfield ">I thank the committee and look forward to your questions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Ambassador Bloomfield "> ---------- </paragraph> <speaker>Chairman Royce</speaker>

<opening>STATEMENT OF THE HONORABLE STEPHEN RADEMAKER, SENIOR OF</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="THE HONORABLE STEPHEN RADEMAKER">Mr. Rademaker. COUNSEL, COVINGTON AND BURLING, LLP (FORMER ASSISTANT SECRETARY</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="THE HONORABLE STEPHEN RADEMAKER"> SECURITY AND NONPROLIFERATION, U.S. DEPARTMENT OF STATE) </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Rademaker</speaker> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">Thank you, Mr. Chairman and Ranking Member Engel and members of the committee. It's a pleasure to appear before you again. I thank you for the invitation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">I want to say at the outset, Mr. Chairman, I agree entirely with your opening statement. I really couldn't have put it better.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">I have submitted a prepared statement. I think it makes a lot of excellent points and I urge you to read it. But since there have been some developments since I wrote the statement, I think I will depart from it and make a few additional points to those in my prepared statement.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">The President, this afternoon, is going to announce his decision. According to press reports, he's going to announce that he's decided not to exercise the waiver authority that he has under existing law, going forward, and thereby allow existing U.S. sanctions required under laws passed by this committee to take effect, which I think would mark a U.S. exit from the JCPOA.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">That will be an unfortunate outcome for all the reasons that Ambassador Bloomfield has identified and I am sure Congresswoman Harmon will make those points as well about the downsides to that outcome.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">The point I want to make is there are basically three ways to avoid that outcome. One is for the President to change his mind. I don't think he's going to change his mind. He's drawn a line in the sand and I think today he's going to announce his determination to adhere to that line.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">So we can sit here and complain that his tactics are all wrong. But I don't think he's going to listen. He's made up his mind and we know what direction he's going.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">The second way to avoid it is the one that you suggested in your opening statement, Mr. Chairman, and that is for the Europeans to reach an agreement with Trump administration to fix the agreement and that--you know, I've observed this closely and I think actually the administration has made a good faith effort to negotiate with the Europeans and has come up with what I would describe as a very modest proposal.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">For a man who declared that this was the worst deal ever, when you look at what he's asking from the Europeans, it's a price for keeping the United States in the deal. It's relatively modest price and, in my opinion, entirely defensible, and I will come to that in a moment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">The third way to avoid it--and it was actually I think President Trump's preferred way to keep the United States in the deal--was for Congress to pass legislation very similar to what he's asked the Europeans for.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">Now, he really looked to the Senate to act on that legislation initially. There was a bill introduced by Chairman Corker and Senator Cotton, and he specifically endorsed that legislation. This was in October of last year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">He called on the Senate to pass that legislation and it was clear that if the Congress enacted that legislation he would keep the United States in the JCPOA.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">That legislation stalled in the Senate. One of the reasons it stalled in the Senate was the Europeans deployed their diplomats to lobby against them and I think that's what accounts for the President's decision in January to sort of shift the onus from the Senate to the Europeans and said, if you want to work against me in the United States Congress, well, I am now going to ask something of you.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">So I think that's sort of how we got to where we are today. But a third solution would be to go back to the Corker-Cotton legislation which, again, I think actually represents a defensible approach to what to do about the fundamental problem we face, which is the sunset clause.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">I think even supporters of the JCPOA acknowledge that the sunset clause is a problem, that effective January 2026 Iran's ability to enrich uranium is going to go up exponentially and their ability to break out and produce nuclear weapons will become quite imminent and what do we do about that.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">In my prepared statement I identify, basically, five options for addressing that problem. One of them is just to accept that idea that Iran will be able to have nuclear weapons if it's wants to after 2026.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Mr. Rademaker">I think that's probably the worst of the options.
